custom_filters module

Custom filters for the handlers inside ConversationHandler in telegram_module. These filters are needed to guide the conversation with the user and interpret the inputs.

class read4me.custom_filters.FilterBotInlineInput(name: str | None = None, data_filter: bool = False)[source]

If the user performs an inline query inside the bot’s private chat, the bot ignores the message that was generated to respond to the inline query itself.

filter(message)[source]

This method must be overwritten.

Args:

message (telegram.Message): The message that is tested.

Returns:

dict or bool

class read4me.custom_filters.FilterTopicsDelete(name: str | None = None, data_filter: bool = False)[source]

The bot expects a number of a target topic to delete during the conversation with the user, no other input is allowed.

filter(message)[source]

This method must be overwritten.

Args:

message (telegram.Message): The message that is tested.

Returns:

dict or bool

class read4me.custom_filters.FilterConfirm(name: str | None = None, data_filter: bool = False)[source]

The bot expects a “yes/no” answer. “yes” is received.

filter(message)[source]

This method must be overwritten.

Args:

message (telegram.Message): The message that is tested.

Returns:

dict or bool

class read4me.custom_filters.FilterDeny(name: str | None = None, data_filter: bool = False)[source]

The bot expects a “yes/no” answer. “no” is received.

filter(message)[source]

This method must be overwritten.

Args:

message (telegram.Message): The message that is tested.

Returns:

dict or bool
